item.title: Netflix Enters Agreement To Buy Warner Bros. For $82 Billion, Includes Game Studios
item.content:encoded:
Mortal Kombat, Batman: Arkham, and more are affected

In a staggering piece of news this Friday, streaming giant Netflix has announced that it has entered an agreement with Warner Bros. Discovery to acquire Warner Bros. in a deal that's valued at roughly $82.7 billion ‚Äî an equity value of $72 billion.

Netflix is specifically acquiring Warner Bros.' Streaming & Studios company, which it created in June 2025 and includes including Game of Thrones, the DC Universe, Harry Potter, Lord of the Rings, and platforms such as HBO and HBO Max and Warner Bros. Games.

The media company doesn't mention WB's gaming division at all in its press release. However, Game Developer has confirmed with a WB spokesperson that "the recently-restructured video game division... will be joining Netflix."

Currently, Warner Bros. Games includes a number of studios such as Rocksteady (Batman: Arkham series), NetherRealm Studios (Mortal Kombat), TT Games (LEGO), Portkey Games, and Avalanche Studios (Harry Potter), along with WB's studios in Boston, Montr√©al, New York, and San Francisco.

It's a huge deal that Netflix expect to take around 12-18 months, but that's if it goes through. We know how long other huge acquisitions have taken. Plus regulators are more than likely to get involved. Paramount had previously attempted to purchase the studio in October, which was rejected.

If successful, Warner Bros. shareholders will receive $27.75 a share along with stock in Netflix and the company expects to make savings of around $2-$3 billion by the third year.

The deal could have a huge impact on these studios, and is yet another example of consolidation in the video game industry at a time when layoffs, game studio sales, and closures are rampant.

In fact, earlier this week, reports emerged that Netflix was selling Spry Fox, developer of Cozy Grove, back to the owners.

We'll update this story if more information comes to light.

[source ir.netflix.net, via gamedeveloper.com]



https://www.nintendolife.com/news/2025/12/netflix-enters-agreement-to-buy-warner-bros-for-usd82-billion-includes-game-studios

item.title: What We Played ‚Äì Metroid Prime 4, Death Howl & Routine
item.content:encoded:
It‚Äôs pretty much time to wrap up the year and put a bow on it, in terms of big game releases. There‚Äôs still a whole host of ports and remasters to come, and the odd indie delight, like Skate Story or Terminator 2D: No Fate, but I think we can all shift focus to awards season and gearing up for Christmas.

But this week did see that one last big first party game, and I got all ‚Äòroided up for its review. Metroided up on Prime, that is. With the game, not the fad energy drink, to be clear. I rather enjoyed Samus‚Äô return, and I‚Äôm already contemplating doing a second run through!

Aran‚Äôs been playing Death Howl for a review that you can expect next week, and also got to share his thoughts about Outward 2 ‚Äì ‚ÄúI learned very quickly the world is an unforgiving place. I died so many times!‚Äù

While he meant to continue playing Ghost of Yotei, Ade just couldn‚Äôt keep himself away from Darktide. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just such a fun game, and the fact that you can easily find time to fit a twenty minute mission into a day makes it ideal for when there‚Äôs not a lot of free time for gaming.‚Äù

Jim did manage to spend some time in Yotei, though only to cross off a few bounties, before playing something much more chilled with Wingspan, the charming card game about collecting birds that he‚Äôd heard good things about.

It‚Äôs mainly been Halls of Torment, Lego Horizon, and Where Winds Meet for Gamoc this week, while Steve has (as usual) distracted himself from the horrors of the real world with the horrors of digital world, ‚Äúwith the retro-futuristic terrors of Routine and the insomniac delights of Sleep Awake.‚Äù

When he hasn‚Äôt been fiddling around with Wi-Fi 7 routers, Dom has played the chaotic physics-based co-op adventure of Cloudheim, and sunk back into Assassin‚Äôs Creed Shadows with the impressive Nintendo Switch 2 port.

And whaddya know? Bungie managed to lure Tuffcub back to Destiny 2 with their Star Wars crossover event. Look out for some thoughts on this a little later today!

Now then, what have you played this week?



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/12/05/what-we-played-metroid-prime-4-death-howl-routine/

item.title: Neath has been revealed as the next game by the Rogue Legacy creators
item.content:encoded:
Cellar Door Games, the studio behind Rogue Legacy and Rogue Legacy 2, has announced its next project, and it is a roguelite tactical RPG called Neath. It is set in a world where the Gods must be obeyed even as they change the rules, while players must lead a group of adventurers through an inverted tower while dealing with monsters and the whims of Fate.

Central to Neath is the lesson that teams need to work together. A main example is the locking system where party members freeze in fear when targeted by an enemy, and the only way to break this is for other members to draw the attention of the foe. As Neath is a roguelike, no run will be exactly the same but you can use resources to build up the town of Shale. Doing so will allow access to different skills that will make runs more manageable and ascendance through the tower more likely. Runs will also have special event encounters that can change up the way things work, as the gods look to keep changing the rules.

No release date has been given for Neath yet, but a demo is expected in 2026. Neath has been confirmed for PC only.

Source: Neath ‚Äì Announcement Trailer



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/12/05/neath-has-been-revealed-as-the-next-game-by-the-rogue-legacy-creators/

item.title: Splitgate 2 Launched, Flopped, Unlaunched, Relaunched, And Renamed All In The Same Year
item.content:encoded:
Splitgate 2, the ‚Äúwhat-if-Halo-but-also-Portal‚Äù shooter, had a rocky launch this year following a controversial Summer Game Fest appearance and aggressive monetization practices. But the game is hoping to open a new chapter with players after it went back into beta status in July 2025, after launching just a month prior. It‚Äôs marking that new chapter with a name change. The game will now be known as Splitgate: Arena Reloaded. A promotional video describes it as being rebuilt ‚Äúfrom the ground up.‚Äù

He‚Äôs changed, babe. For real this time.

In a video posted to the official Splitgate YouTube channel (h/t Eurogamer), 1047 Games‚Äô design director Josh Watson describes the game as a tribute to classic arena shooters such as Unreal, Quake, and of course, Halo. To that end, Splitgate has ejected factions and unique abilities to hopefully lock into that old-school arena style gameplay, just with fancy portals. The full experience is expected to launch for free on December 17, 2025. Check out the gameplay here:

Splitgate managed to really step in it this summer after director Ian Proulx took to the Summer Game Fest stage in 2025 to deliver an obtuse rant about the state of modern shooters, all while sporting a ‚ÄúMake FPS Great Again‚Äù hat. As if that wasn‚Äôt enough, Splitgate 2 featured many uncomfortable trappings of modern shooters: aggressive microtransactions and costly cosmetic bundles. And for a game that promised to return to a classic style of shooter gameplay, the inclusion of a battle royale mode was odd.

As such, the release of the sequel didn‚Äôt go over well with fans. In response, 1047 Games pulled its shooter back into an indefinite beta status to rework the experience five months ago. Whether it will be enough to smooth things over with folks remains to be seen.

Splitgate impressed early on in 2019 with its fusion of classic arena shooter gameplay with portal shenanigans. They could be prone to gimmicky plays, but tossing portals into the mess of traditional arena-shooter action often proved to be a nice change of pace. Let‚Äôs see if its second emergence from beta and the new name will be enough for the sequel to make waves again.



https://kotaku.com/splitgate-2-arena-shooter-beta-1047-games-2000650903

item.title: Roku Goes Into Clearance Mode on Streambar and Subwoofer Bundle at Record Low, While Amazon Fire TV Soundbar Returns to Full Price
item.content:encoded:
Still got a ‚Äúdumb‚Äù TV lacking all the smart features we‚Äôve seen become a standard over the last decade? No need to upgrade just yet if it‚Äôs still working fine. Maybe just need to bring it into the modern age with the help of a Roku. They‚Äôre budget-friendly and simple to set up. And conveniently enough, Amazon is currently offering the Roku 4K HDR Streambar SE and Wireless Bass Bundle at a 35% discount. It‚Äôs usually listed at $230, but for a short period you can grab it for only $150‚Äîmeaning you keep an extra $80 in your pocket.

Whether you‚Äôre trying to start streaming on a non-smart TV or you‚Äôre just not a fan of your smart TV‚Äôs clunky interface (looking at you, LG), plugging a Roku into one of your free HDMI ports is can make for a better experience. You‚Äôll be able to access all the apps you rely on to stay caught up with new releases. Every Roku streaming device includes Bluetooth support and works with both Google Assistant and Amazon Alexa, letting it smoothly integrate into your broader smart home setup. Its remote also features a built-in voice assistant, making it simple to search for whatever content you‚Äôre looking for.

See at Amazon

And speaking of the remote, it‚Äôs rechargeable, so you no longer need to stock AAAs. The backlit buttons make it easy to navigate in dim lighting without the usual fumbling around. Of course, you can also just say ‚ÄúHey Roku‚Äù and control everything via voice commands instead. If the remote ever goes missing, Roku even provides a lost-remote finder. Though, it‚Äôs probably slipped somewhere between your couch cushions. Maybe just check there.

The home screen is completely customizable, allowing you to keep your preferred streaming apps front and center. An interesting bonus‚ÄîRoku actually has its own original programming. Alongside the apps you already subscribe to like Hulu, Netflix, Disney+, and Max, you can switch over to enjoy Roku‚Äôs free original series such as Dinner Budget Showdown, Celebrity Family Food Battle, Martha Cooks, and Emeril Cooks. I promise, there‚Äôs more than only cooking shows. I just have food on the mind.

Better Sound

This holiday season bundle isn‚Äôt the standard Roku streamer. This is a multimedia player and speaker in one. This Roku soundbar sits under your TV so you can enjoy upgraded sound with all your shows and movies. The soundbar‚Äîor Streambar, rather‚Äîis both your sound output and the source of the Roku interface itself. It just needs to plug into your TV over HDMI and you‚Äôre set.

The bundle is also throwing in the Roku Wireless Bass. This can kick your already great sound up a notch by bringing a subwoofer into the mix.

Go grab some snacks and let everyone know that the next movie night will be happening in your living room‚Äîthanks to the Roku Streambar SE and Wireless Bass bundle, now available for just $150. I‚Äôd recommend putting that $70 you‚Äôre saving toward a popcorn machine.

See at Amazon

item.title: Mortal Kombat‚Äôs Shang Tsung, Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, Has Died Aged 75
item.content:encoded:
Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa was an actor that everyone would immediately recognize, but perhaps many would struggle to name. Known best for his portrayal of Shang Tsung in 1995‚Äôs ridiculous Mortal Kombat movie, and then for voicing the character in the games since 2013, Tagawa had multiple other defining roles across an extraordinary career. Deadline reports he died on December 4, following complications from a stroke.

It‚Äôs hard to think of a more iconic role than Shang Tsung, the evil sorcerer in Paul W.S. Anderson‚Äôs hokey and adored 1995 adaptation of the Mortal Kombat video game series, as well as 2013‚Äôs web series Mortal Kombat: Legacy (then once more in 2015‚Äôs abandoned promotional web series, Mortal Kombat X: Generations). But Tagawa had broad range, known more recently for his leading role as the noble and conflicted Nobusuke Tagomi in Amazon‚Äôs The Man in the High Castle, as well as roles as diverse as Krull in Tim Burton‚Äôs Planet of the Apes, Hiroki Watanabe in Lost in Space, and multiple guest roles on a number of popular TV series. He also displayed a splendid lack of brand loyalty when he appeared in 2010‚Äôs atrocious movie version of Tekken! (As well as its straight-to-video sequel.)

Tagawa was also a voice actor, portraying Valco in Star Wars: Visions, The Swordmaker in Netflix‚Äôs animation Blue Eye Samurai, and Alrich Wren in Star Wars: Rebels, among many others. He was a contributor to video game voice roles, too, again most notably reprising his role as Shang Tsung in various Mortal Kombat games, including Mortal Kombat 11 and its various DLCs. The actor is also heard in World of Warcraft: Legion, and 2003‚Äôs Batman: Rise of Sin Tzu as the eponymous criminal. Oh, and rather brilliantly, he appeared in the extraordinary mess of 1997‚Äôs FMV game Soldier Boyz, a game that claimed to be co-directed by Darren Aronofsky, given the footage was lifted from an HBO TV show.

The Toyko-born actor trained in martial arts as a child, before studying karate at university. His first movie appearance was Bernardo Bertolucci‚Äôs Oscar-winning The Last Emperor in 1987, before going on to appear in 150 other roles. Tagawa died on Thursday morning, surrounded by his family, aged 75. RIP.



https://kotaku.com/mortal-kombat-shang-tsung-cary-hiroyuki-tagawa-died-2000650880

item.title: Running With Scissors Cancels Postal: Bullet Paradise Within A Day
item.content:encoded:
Running With Scissors has canceled its upcoming game Postal: Bullet Paradise roughly 24 hours after it was revealed.

On December 3, the publisher announced the new ‚Äúbullet-heaven shooter‚Äù from developer Goonswarm Games. After the reveal trailer went live, fan feedback was negative, with claims that it used a number of AI-generated assets.

That quickly led to a decision to pull the plug on the game just over a day after it was announced.

In a statement provided to press and shared online, Running With Scissors founder Vince Desi says that the decisions comes after being ‚Äúoverwhelmed with negative responses‚Äù from fans of the series.

After revealing POSTAL: Bullet Paradise, a title Running With Scissors was planning on publishing but not developing, we‚Äôve been overwhelmed with negative responses from our concerned POSTAL Community. The strong feedback from them is that elements of the game are very likely AI-generated and thus has caused extreme damage to our brand and our company reputation.

We‚Äôve always been, and will always be, transparent with our community. Our trust in the development team is broken; therefore, we‚Äôve killed the project. We have a lot of good things coming (some you know and some you don‚Äôt).

Since forming Running With Scissors in 1996, we‚Äôve always said that our fans are part of the team. Our priority is to always do right by the millions who support the POSTAL franchise. We are grateful for the opportunity to make the games we want to play, and will continue to focus on our new projects and updates coming in 2026 and beyond. We can‚Äôt wait to share more!

Currently, Running With Scissors is working on a remake of 2003‚Äôs Postal 2, called Postal 2 Redux. The studio ran a Kickstarter for the game, which raised $638,574 against a target goal of just $250,000. It‚Äôs the second remake in the franchise after Postal Redux was released back in 2016.

Insider Gaming has attempted to contact Goonswarm Games, but no response has been received. Should that happen, it will be added to this story and shared on Insider Gaming‚Äôs social media channels.

You can check out the trailer for Postal: Bullet Paradise for yourself, below. And leave your thoughts on this whole situation down in the comments or in the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more Insider Gaming, check out everything that was announced during Thursday‚Äôs PC Gaming Show: Most Wanted. And don‚Äôt forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: Fallout Creator Rejoins Obsidian, Has A New Squirrel Friend
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Fallout creator Tim Cain has returned to Obsidian, but what is he working on? He's not allowed to say, and says you shouldn't even try to guess. Cain also shared an update about his personal life and a new friendship with a squirrel.

In a YouTube video, Cain said he recently relocated from Seattle to southern California, and one of the first things that happened was a squirrel ran up to him with no fear. "She just sat there and looked at me, and I shrugged and I'm like, 'What do you want from me? I don't know you.'" Cain fed the critter some walnuts and continues to feed the creature every day when he leaves and comes back home.

This is how Cain started the video, before getting into his return to Obsidian. He said he's now back at the studio, in-person and full-time. While he has returned to Obsidian, you'll also see his name appear in the credits of an upcoming unspecified game that he did contract work for before coming back to Obsidian, he said.

Cain also mentioned that he did contract work for multiple other games, but they are unlikely to be released. He said the years 2020-2025 were a "weird time in the industry" when lots of games began production and then got canceled, for a variety of reasons. "I really don't know the status of all the games I contracted on," he said.

As for his current project at Obsidian, Cain said he cannot talk about because "that's covered under NDA." He added, "Don't bother guessing--you're not going to guess right."

Cain was one of the core designers of the 1997 original Fallout at Interplay Productions. He also worked on the sequel, along with games like South Park: The Stick of Truth and Pillars of Eternity. He was the game director on The Outer Worlds and a creative consultant for The Outer Worlds 2.

Obsidian has had a busy 2025, releasing Avowed in February 2025, Grounded 2 in July, and The Outer Worlds 2 in October. The studio has no confirmed and announced upcoming games, but we do know that Cain is working on whatever Obsidian may be cooking up next.

Cain said he's coming out of "semi-retirement" to return to Obsidian. Before this, he was doing the previously mentioned contract work, and making videos for his "Cain on Games" YouTube channel. This channel will continue going forward, he said, adding that no one at Obsidian told him to stop.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Mortal Kombat Actor Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa Passes Away At 75
item.content:encoded:
Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa, whose credits span TV and films like Memoirs of a Geisha, The Man in the High Castle, and 1995‚Äôs Mortal Kombat, died yesterday due to complications from a stroke, Deadline reports. He was 75.

Tagawa‚Äôs acting career spanned over four decades, with film credits including The Last Emperor, Rising Sun, Memoirs of a Geisha, Planet of the Apes (2000), Balls of Fury, 47 Ronin, and Kubo and the Two Strings. In television, he appeared in series including MacGyver, Star Trek: The Next Generation, Star Wars: Rebels, and most notably as Nobusuke Tagomi in Amazon Prime‚Äôs The Man in the High Castle. Tagawa‚Äôs final role was as Master Eiji in the 2023 Netflix animated series Blue Samurai.  

Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa as Shang Tsung in Mortal Kombat (1995)

For video game fans, Tagawa was best known for portraying Shang Tsung in the first live-action Mortal Kombat film. His performance as the villainous sorcerer, which featured now-famous lines like "Your soul is mine!" and "It has begun!", became so beloved that he would reprise the role in various adaptations, such as the 2013 web series Mortal Kombat: Legacy. Tagawa also appeared as Shang Tsung, voice and likeness, in Mortal Kombat 11‚Äôs Aftermath story expansion and the mobile action RPG Mortal Kombat: Onslaught.

Mortal Kombat co-creator Ed Boon shared his condolences on X, writing

We lost a legend today. 

Cary-Hiroyuki Tagawa played Shang Tsung in the 1995 Mortal Kombat film and sadly passed away at age 75. We had the privilege of his portrayal on the first MK film but also as an amazing voice actor in the Mortal Kombat 11 game.

Cary was one of a kind. He combined danger, swagger and athleticism to his roles and will always be remembered as the man who first brought Shang Tsung to life on film.

Rest in Peace. Your soul is eternal.

While closely tied to Shang Tsung, Tagawa had also portrayed another iconic fighting game villain. He played Heihachi Mishima in the live-action movie Tekken, which was released in the US in 2011, and its 2014 sequel, Tekken 2: Kazuya‚Äôs Revenge. Tagawa had voice credits in other video games: World of Warcraft: Legion, Batman: Rise of Sun Tzu, and Soldier Boyz. 

As reported by Deadline, Tagawa's family confirmed he died Thursday, surrounded by his children. 



https://gameinformer.com/obituary/2025/12/05/mortal-kombat-actor-cary-hiroyuki-tagawa-passes-away-at-75

item.title: "It's totally nonsensical!" Final Fantasy 14 composer's dream comes true, as game gets collaboration with Rage Against The Machine's Tom Morello
item.content:encoded:
It's an "absolute rocking banger of a track".

Rage Against The Machine guitarist Tom Morello has written a new song for Final Fantasy 14, making composer Masayoshi Soken's dreams come true.

The MMORPG has long had a heavy influence of rock music in its score. Jason Charles Miller, lead vocalist and guitarist of the band Godhead, lent his vocals to the game, singing Endwalker's iconic song Close in the Distance (a personal favourite), while the game's developers themselves have formed a rock band called The Primals.

Earlier this year, I asked the game's composer why he leans on rock music for inspiration. "Battle content really matches well with rock music," he said. "Musically, rock is something that is easy to hype up to, and it's also easy to understand, even though rock is not necessarily the only thing that would get you excited. I just think, as a genre, it's very easy to get involved in."

What's more, Soken told me Rage Against The Machine is his favourite band, so this collaboration is very much a full circle moment.

"It all started when Jason Charles Miller told me that Soken-san, the composer of Final Fantasy 14, was a huge Rage Against The Machine fan and wanted to collaborate," said Morello in a video message shared on social media.

"So I got down to work and wrote this track‚Ä¶with Beartooth, a great band. We wanted to make something super heavy and super powerful for Final Fantasy 14. I wanted to make an absolute rocking banger of a track that would mirror the energy and the potency of this game."

Light it up, let's go! üî•

A new song by award-winning guitarist Tom Morello, featuring Beartooth, is making its way onto the Arcadion stage in FFXIV!

Here's a message from Tom and a preview of the upcoming track, Everything Burns! pic.twitter.com/1htLXi2V1c

‚Äî FINAL FANTASY XIV (@FF_XIV_EN) December 5, 2025

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Soken shared the post himself, calling it "nonsensical" - he's clearly very excited.

"To write it in an easy-to-understand way? Suddenly, a song gets sent from my top fave, and it gets implemented in the game - that's the flow, and even as I'm writing this now, it's totally nonsensical!" he said (via machine translation).

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

The track, called Everything Burns, will feature in the Arcadion battle arena. It'll also be available on streaming services from 17th December. Before then, you can hear a snippet in both the social posts and trailer above.

The next update for Final Fantasy 14, Patch 7.4, will be added on 16th December. Called Into The Mist, it will lift restrictions on glamouring outfits in addition to extending the game's story.

Related topics

item.title: Grasshopper Manufacture‚Äôs Romeo Is A Dead Man lands in February
item.content:encoded:
Overnight, Grasshopper Manufacture had its own mini showcase in which it announced that its action game Romeo Is A Dead Man will be released on February 11th. To mark the announcement, a brand new trailer for the game was released, and it is as strange as you would expect from the mind of Suda51 and the team at Grasshopper Manufacture.

Romeo Is A Dead Man‚Äôs story set up is a bit wild too. Space-time has been shattered and just as Romeo is about to die he is saved by the Dead Gear Life Support System, which turns him into cyborg. He is then recruited to the FBI‚Äôs Space-Time Police to hunt down criminals taking advantage of the chaos, while also on a mission to find his girlfriend Juliet. Romeo and Juliet. Get it?

Suda51‚Äôs last game was No More Heroes 3, of which Nick said, ‚ÄúNo More Heroes 3 shines with its fourth-wall-breaking self-awareness, zany characters and stunningly slick combat. It‚Äôs not afraid to be what it is, Suda 51 and his team delivering a great instalment to the franchise that welcomes us to the Garden of Insanity.‚Äù

Romeo Is  A Dead Man will launch on PC, PS5, and Xbox Series XS.

Source: YouTube



https://www.thesixthaxis.com/2025/12/05/grasshopper-manufactures-romeo-is-a-dead-man-lands-in-february/

item.title: Men In Black: Most Wanted Review - Once You Go Worm...
item.content:encoded:
Men In Black was an absolute highlight of the 90s and early 2000s entertainment. Threading the needle perfectly between pop culture, conspiracy, and digital and practical effects, it was a world that felt believable because it was just close enough to our own with a bit of fantasy. Coatsink has sought to bring back that magic with Men In Black: Most Wanted, an MIB VR adventure set in the 90s as you take on the role of Agent I, working to stop a new alien threat coming to earth.

Agent 'I Don't Remember'

Men In Black: Most Wanted opens as you come to consciousness, having accidentally neuralyzed yourself. Being quickly surrounded by aliens, you have to quickly make your way back to your car, and the MIB headquarters to be debriefed.

Here, you learn of a plot for Aliens to slowly invade the Earth, while you know that there's a grander conspiracy. At this time, the only activity you've heard of is some small-time smugglers. The plot thickens further as you're told that the only way you could have been ambushed in the way you were‚Ä¶ would be if there was a mole in the MIB.

Armed with the knowledge of an alien to track down at a Motel, and the common sense to keep your mission a secret, you head out to begin your mission to topple this alien invasion.

From here, your adventure takes you to a variety of interesting locations, such as a dockyard or office building, where you enter under the guise of an inspector or someone with a meeting before uncovering the aliens hiding in plain sight.

I was a huge fan of the mission formula. Each mission takes you through investigation segments, where you explore the environment, stay away from suspicious eyes, and make your way deeper into any of the facilities. You'll normally be searching for clues related to alien activity, access cards, or solutions to other smaller puzzles to make your way deeper in.

The exploration sections weren't difficult; they reminded me of action-adventure games from the PS2 era, but getting to complete them in VR added a new sense of fun. Something that would feel basic in a 2D video game, like opening a few drawers without being spotted for a keycard, added a new sense of tension when you had to physically spin around to check and make sure the coast was clear.

Once you've completed some puzzles, you'll ultimately end up in an alien base where you'll be ducking energy blasts and taking out aliens before they take you out. There are all of the classic hallmarks of an arcadey shooter, with ways to take out enemies from stealth and giant red barrels to shoot, all culminating in some kind of boss encounter.

Walk Like An MIB Agent

The controls for Men In Black: Most Wanted are nice and intuitive. Moving with the left stick and pivoting with the right, your health bar is on your wristwatch, and at any time, you can pull up your mission status by bringing your left hand to your temple.

Your wristwatch is also where you can pull out and store your equipment. The stowing of items is partially to help keep everything in a single place to pull from, but it also adds to the gameplay, as MIB tech will be investigated by onlookers. Keeping it stowed means more effort to get out, but you fly under the radar.

Men In Black: Most Wanted really lets you go through the whole experience of a MIB agent, showing up to a location with some made up name and agency, lets you investigate for clues, and if an onlooker gets too suspicious, you get to neuralize them.

Quite nicely, each level is also only ~40-50 minutes, depending on how stumped you get by the puzzles. I found that this was the perfect length for me for a single session before I started feeling any kind of adverse effects from so much running, ducking, and shooting in VR.

An Agent Is Only As Good As His Tools

As you progress through each level, you earn more and more tools that become relevant to the next mission. Early on, I was unsurprised by the abilities I got, like a glove that let me move metal objects around regardless of their weight. This leans heavily into VR-friendly object movement as you just raise a hand and grip to move a metal box or vent grate off the wall.

The tool that I loved the most was the spider-like robot that can walk on walls and short-circuit electricity. You can pluck it from your inventory and lob it in any direction or through an appropriately sized gap. Once the robot sets itself up, you raise your right hand to your head to swap control to the robot. Another fantastic way to make what could be a complicated button combination incredibly easy to perform in VR.

As the robot, you can also leap on walls, twisting your perspective of the world and opening up new avenues for puzzle solving.

As you progress through the game, you can also upgrade the weapons you get by spending collectible points on them. You can modify weapons to have charged blasts or fire ricochet bullets to change up how you're playing the game.

A Cartoon Look, But Not THE Cartoon Look

Men In Black: Most Wanted has a fun art style that's a mix of what you'd expect from a comic or a '90s cartoon. That being said, it's not as stylized as the old cartoon, which is a bit of a shame.

Most Wanted falls into that really good level of graphics for mobile VR that's showing you something that you can accept and be a part of the world as, without trying to push too hard for a level of realism that would leave the user stuck in an uncanny universe.

This cartoonish style also lends itself fantastically to the big pops of color that separate the mundane and boring world of the city with alien artifacts and blood.

Invasion Mode Is VR Horde Mode

When you're done playing the 8-10 hour campaign, you can take on the Invasion mode on your own or with others online. Invasion Mode is as you'd expect, you take on waves of enemies with a variety of different objectives and try to make it as far as you can on a single life.

After each round, you can purchase an upgrade for yourself or your weapons or consumable items. The points you spend are earned by defeating enemies. Each enemy I killed rewarded me with a different amount of points; I couldn't quite tell what was determining that amount or if it was mostly random.

On top of killing aliens, you might also be searching the arena for objectives like power sources to place in receptacles around the arena.

The purchases expand even further past upgrades, as you can also buy arena obstacles and turrets. These items let you reshape the terrain and add a bit of random/uniqueness, but in your favor.

Men In Black: Most Wanted Review | Final Thoughts

Men In Black: Most Wanted from start to finish felt like discovering a classic Action Adventure title from the ~PS2 era of gaming. The gameplay is a fun mix between some engaging problem-solving and sleuthing before it moves into frantic shootouts against colorful aliens.

Coatsink has done a fantastic job crafting a mission-based story to lead you through the alien underground, pulling the threads of a conspiracy for a fun and engaging payoff.

Coupled with easy to learn and dynamic VR controls, an art style that fits the subject well and welcomes you to the world, and a reasonable play session time matched to the story beats of a mission whether you're a massive fan of MIB, or are just looking for a great action adventure title to play on your Quest next I'd definitely recommend this.

Men In Black: Most Wanted was reviewed on Meta Quest 3 with a copy provided by the Developer over the course of 9 hours of gameplay - all screenshots were taken during the process of review.

Andrew has written Video Game and Entertainment news, reviews, and guides for 10+ years. As Senior Content Manager, he assists in creating and editing‚Ä¶ More about Andrew

item.title: Waiting for the Other Cleat to Drop
item.content:encoded:
Fandom is, itself, illogical.

You do not control the team. You do not control the outcome. And yet, the vast majority of the population willingly subjects themselves to stop to regular emotional torture rooting for some kind of team.

Given how little control we have over other parts of our lives, maybe it makes sense. If the seeming randomness of sports can make us happy, maybe there will be a roll of the dice in another direction, too?

Well, if you're a Chicago Bears fan, that's probably not something to count on. But this year has been different. Special? Maybe not. Different? Yes. Patrick is ready to ride the bronco and see where it takes him, while Rob remains...you know, let's call it skeptical.

Rob: If you had told me back in August that I would spend part of Thanksgiving Weekend watching the Chicago Bears pulverize Philadelphia Eagles and that they would be the number one team in the NFC, I would have assumed that there was some kind of freakish midair collision that involved multiple teams' charter planes. That the Bears would be winning these games wearing blacked-out logos for the Packers and Eagles on their uniforms. And yet here we are: the Bears are 9-3 and likely headed for the playoffs.

The thing is, Patrick, I can't shake the feeling that this is 2018 all over again. An offensive-minded culture guy has sparked a formerly moribund franchise. The quarterback frequently looks mediocre but with flashes of excellence, and the defense is getting turnovers even as they give up lots of yards. The Bears could easily be 3-9 if one thing goes differently in each of those six one-score wins. If we're being honest, a lot of those games have been pretty uninspiring. "Another fraudulent Bears win!" is what you yelled as we celebrated at the Bills game, and you could have said that about quite a few of those victories.

It's hard for me to enjoy the ride this time around because 2018 was a false dawn that heralded years of deepening dysfunction, winning too much trust for a front office and coaching staff that didn't deserve it. By the end of 2019 it was abundantly clear why Matt Nagy's and Mitch Trubisky's Bears needed so many fluke wins and when the luck ran out, so did any joy in watching our football team.

So I find myself dreading the next month of football, and in particular this weekend. Because the Bears are playing the Packers, and the schedule looks brutal from here, with rematches with the Lions and Packers both upcoming plus a game against the 49ers. In previous years, the Bears were so hopeless that you weren't really publicly shamed for being a fan because nobody was seeing their games outside of ritual sacrifices on Sunday and Monday night football. Now? Patrick, everybody is paying attention to our Bears! There's a good chance four of those next five games are going to be nationally featured. And dude, I just don't want this team to be an embarrassment anymore. I am sick of the texts from friends at halftime of a Sunday night disaster: "Yo is it always like this?" Yeah, historically, it is. This is my team. This is what shaped me.

Patrick: Dude, I‚Äôm sorry, but you have to stop this. Line in the sand. This team is fun. No, they‚Äôre not a Super Bowl team. Yes, they‚Äôve won a bunch of coin flip games. But trust your eyes: this is a foundation.

Every basic and advanced statistic about the Chicago Bears tells you what they‚Äôre doing is real. The ‚Äúmaybe not 100% real‚Äù part is wins, but I‚Äôm sorry, this entire NFL season is about mid teams fighting one another. There is no dominant force in either conference. How else do you explain that if the Bears lose to the Packers, they move from the one to the seven seed? It‚Äôs a wholly unique year in a sport where weird shit happens and this is just a year where weird shit is happening to the Bears and they also happen to be putting things together at the right time of the year.

I‚Äôm done caveating all of that! The Bears are fun, man.

Library, Zeal or Foundation tier

Subscribe at Library, Zeal or Foundation tier(s) or above to access "Waiting for the Other Cleat to Drop". You'll also get access to the full back catalog of that tier's content.

The 17.3-inch HP touchscreen laptop, which usually sits well over $2,600, is currently going for just $770 at Amazon, after a whopping 70% off its usual price. It‚Äôs the lowest we have seen it drop to in a month, and the retailer is also throwing in a bunch of useful accessories for absolutely nothing. Windows 11 Pro also comes pre-installed, so you‚Äôre saving a good chunk on that front, too. Be sure to grab yours fast, as we don‚Äôt expect the discount to stay around for long. In fact, it might not even make it into the weekend.

See at Amazon

Massive Display, Fast Performance

You‚Äôre getting a massive 17.3-inch Brightview HD+ touch display that brings content to life in stunning 1600 x 900 resolution. 1.4M pixels come together to deliver every detail with incredible accuracy, while the slim bezel and 16:9 aspect ratio offer quite a lot of room to work and play. You can stream your favorite shows, create presentations, and even play some of your favorite titles; all without feeling cramped. There‚Äôs an HP TrueVision 720p HD, paired with temporal noise reduction and an integrated dual array digital microphone for better video calls. Additionally, audio quality is just as great, thanks to the built-in Dual-stereo speakers.

For power, HP has packed the laptop with a 6-core AMD Ryzen 5 7530U Processor that is capable of hitting speeds up to 4.5 GHz. It‚Äôs more than enough to speed through a bunch of work and creative tasks without a hint of lag. The 16GB RAM isn‚Äôt massive, but still modest enough to keep things running smoothly, especially when you‚Äôre trying to multitask. You will be able to work with different applications at the same time ‚Äì think catching up on Slack, hopping on a meeting with Zoom, working on a PowerPoint project ‚Äì without slowing down. Storing all your important data in a single place is made easy with the built-in 512GB SSD. It should be enough for most users out there, unless you‚Äôre trying to store an entire gaming library on it. And since the storage is expandable, you always pair it with an SD card or an external hard drive to get the space you need. SSDs are also much faster than traditional drives, so you‚Äôre going to enjoy faster boot and load times as well.

The battery is solid, and HP Fast Charge gets it back up and running in no time when you‚Äôre running low. As for the freebies, you‚Äôll get Windows 11 Pro pre-installed, a CD/DVD drive, a cleaning cloth, a wireless mouse, and a 256GB Micro SD. That‚Äôs everything you need to get started right away.

If you‚Äôve been looking to grab a solid laptop without blowing your budget, this 17.3-inch HP touchscreen laptop is an excellent option to consider, especially at its current price. You‚Äôre paying $770 for features that are usually reserved for high-end models. We recommend the machine to work professionals, students, creatives, and even casual users. Make sure you get your orders in quick, because the deal could expire at any moment now.

item.title: Dragon Age Day Comes And Goes In Complete Silence Just One Year After Veilguard
item.content:encoded:
December 4th is Dragon Age Day, the unofficial day fans of BioWare‚Äôs fantasy RPG anthology celebrate the series. Last year, the studio earnestly participated. Dragon Age: The Veilguard was only about a month old at the time, so BioWare released the game‚Äôs incredible character creator for free and broke down early player choices on social media. This year? There wasn‚Äôt a peep from the studio on the matter. Not even a single mention of the franchise that once won ‚ÄúBest Game‚Äù at the Game Awards.

If you look at BioWare‚Äôs Dragon Age social accounts, the last time the studio used the game‚Äôs X account was to repost an ad for The Veilguard on the EA Play subscription service on August 28. The developer‚Äôs official blog‚Äôs last post was on November 7, celebrating Mass Effect‚Äôs equivalent ‚Äúholiday,‚Äù N7 Day, which had a small update on the upcoming fifth game and the Amazon television series. You‚Äôll find no such post about Dragon Age. BioWare has admitted it‚Äôs become a one-game studio after massive layoffs back in January, so there is no fifth Dragon Age game in the works, but the silence also casts a shadow on the RPG series‚Äô past. 

If you‚Äôre only passively paying attention, it might make sense for the studio to not make a big deal about a series without a sequel it‚Äôs actively promoting. But for fans and the developers who spent decades working on Dragon Age, it‚Äôs another insult to beloved games that seemed to sometimes get the short end of the stick over their troubled development.

In the months since BioWare was gutted of veteran talent and Dragon Age: The Veilguard was thrown under the bus by parent company Electronic Arts, developers have been candid about how the Dragon Age team felt like it wasn‚Äôt treated fairly by the broader company. The Veilguard‚Äôs messy production saw the game rebooted from a live service no one wanted into a single-player RPG that, miraculously, came out feeling like the character-driven epics BioWare is associated with despite being a decade in the works. 

After the game didn‚Äôt reach internal projections out of the gate, EA downsized BioWare and has focused the company exclusively on Mass Effect, and implied that The Veilguard may have reached a broader audience if it had stayed a live service game no one asked for.

So perhaps it‚Äôs for the best that BioWare didn‚Äôt acknowledge Dragon Age this year. If the company had even made a tweet or blog post expressing its love for the world of Thedas and pride in having brought it to life, the messaging would have come across as tone-deaf after the hell its team reportedly went through. 

At least this way, the fans and creatives who made these games get the day to themselves, without it being co-opted by a studio and publisher that treated them like second-class citizens. Now, the Dragon Age team gets the final word.

item.title: Netflix to acquire Warner Bros.
item.content:encoded:
Acquisition to occur following the separation of Discovery Global.

Netflix will acquire Warner Bros. in a $72 billion deal expected to close after the previously announced separation of Warner Bros. Discovery‚Äôs Global Networks division, Discovery Global, into a new publicly-traded company, which is expected to be completed in Q3 2026, the company announced.

The acquisition will bring franchises, shows, and movies such as The Big Bang Theory, The Sopranos, Game of Thrones, The Wizard of Oz, and the DC Universe to Netflix‚Äôs extensive portfolio, as well as brands like HBO and HBO Max.

In the video games space, the acquisition means Warner Bros. Games and its subsidiaries‚Äîincluding Avalanche Software, NetherRealm Studios, Portkey Games, Rocksteady Studios, TT Games, WB Games Boston, WB Games Montreal, WB Games New York, and WB Games San Francisco‚Äîwill soon be under the Netflix banner.

‚ÄúOur mission has always been to entertain the world,‚Äù said Netflix co-CEO Ted Sarandos in a press release. ‚ÄúBy combining Warner Bros.‚Äô incredible library of shows and movies‚Äîfrom timeless classics like Casablancaand Citizen Kaneto modern favorites like Harry Potter and Friends‚Äîwith our culture-defining titles like Stranger Things, KPop Demon Hunters, and Squid Game, we‚Äôll be able to do that even better. Together, we can give audiences more of what they love and help define the next century of storytelling.‚Äù

Netflix co-CEO Greg Peters continued, ‚ÄúThis acquisition will improve our offering and accelerate our business for decades to come. Warner Bros. has helped define entertainment for more than a century and continues to do so with phenomenal creative executives and production capabilities. With our global reach and proven business model, we can introduce a broader audience to the worlds they create‚Äîgiving our members more options, attracting more fans to our best-in-class streaming service, strengthening the entire entertainment industry and creating more value for shareholders.‚Äù

Warner Bros. Discover president and CEO David Zaslav said, ‚ÄúToday‚Äôs announcement combines two of the greatest storytelling companies in the world to bring to even more people the entertainment they love to watch the most. For more than a century, Warner Bros. has thrilled audiences, captured the world‚Äôs attention, and shaped our culture. By coming together with Netflix, we will ensure people everywhere will continue to enjoy the world‚Äôs most resonant stories for generations to come.‚Äù



https://www.gematsu.com/2025/12/netflix-to-acquire-warner-bros

item.title: Rhell: Warped Worlds & Troubled Times for PC launches March 19, 2026
item.content:encoded:
• PC

Semi-open-world puzzle adventure game dated.

Semi-open-world puzzle adventure game Rhell: Warped Worlds & Troubled Times will launch for PC via Steam on March 19, 2026, publisher Yogscast Games and developer SlugGlove announced. PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, PlayStation 4, Xbox One versions will follow at a later date. A demo is available now.

Here is an overview of the game, via Yogscast Games:

About

Rhell: Warped Worlds & Troubled Times is a semi-open world puzzle adventure where you play as a loud-mouthed, hot-headed mage trying to figure out why everyone has disappeared. With 40 magical runes to combine however you want, every challenge is an opportunity to create your own solution.

What if Every Puzzle Had Multiple Solutions, and Half of Them Were Things You Invented?

You start with four runes and collect more as you explore the world of Rhell, using up to five of these in whatever combination you please to solve different puzzles. Want to hold down two buttons, but you‚Äôve only got yourself? Duplicate yourself and turn your copy into a puddle that permanently holds the switch down. Need a vehicle in a quick fix? Cast Life on a rock and use it as your pet car! Whatever the combination, whatever the solution, the magic is yours to master.

The World‚Äôs Gone Quiet

Everyone has vanished except 12 people, leaving behind empty towns and unanswered questions. As Rhell, a sharp-tongued mage, you explore forgotten ruins filled with ancient secrets, decode mysterious fragments left behind by those who came before, and slowly piece together what really caused this catastrophe. The few remaining inhabitants have their theories, but you might find a truth far stranger than anyone suspected. What started as a simple mystery becomes something that challenges everything you thought you knew.

Discover Your Own Path

Wander through nine distinct areas at your own pace ‚Äì from flooded libraries and underwater cities to volcanic factories and crystal caves. Each location tells its own story through environmental details and hidden lore, along with characters that have their own mysteries to unravel. Some areas connect in unexpected ways, rewarding those who explore thoroughly. The world doesn‚Äôt just contain puzzles, it is a puzzle‚Äîone that reveals more of itself the deeper you dig. Whether you‚Äôre following the main plot or getting side-tracked by a curious detail, there‚Äôs always another secret waiting just around the corner.

Shape Your Story

If you choose to help the people you meet along your journey, you might see Rhell‚Äôs character develop. Help the lonely characters and watch her soften into someone who genuinely cares. Ignore them entirely and she‚Äôll stay the blunt, loud-mouthed mage she started as. With multiple endings to discover, let your curiosity and kindness (or lack thereof) lead you.

Key Features

  • 40 magical runes creating millions of spell combinations (102,400,000 to be exact!).
  • Creative ways to solve each puzzle‚Äîdo it your own way!
  • Semi-open world with nine distinct areas to explore.
  • Hours of gameplay with endless experimentation and replayability.
  • Rich, story driven narrative with branching paths and multiple endings.
  • Sarcastic, sassy mage who accidentally helps people while being rude about it.

Watch a new trailer below.

Release Date Trailer

item.title: Yes, Netflix is acquiring Warner Bros. Games
item.content:encoded:
Chris Kerr, Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

December 5, 2025

3 Min Read

Logo via Netflix / Screenshot via WB Games

Netflix is acquiring Warner Bros Discovery, the parent company of HBO and Warner Bros. Games, in a cash and stock transaction worth $82.7 billion. It's a notable move for the entertainment industry that will make Netflix the owner of major film and television franchises such as Harry Potter, Game of Thrones, White Lotus, The Sopranos, and the wider DC Universe. 

Notably, a Warner Bros. Discovery spokesperson has confirmed that Warner Bros. Games is included in the transaction.

When discussing the move, Netflix‚Äîwhich has been attempting (and generally struggling) to make inroads into the video game industry‚Äîlargely focused on the benefits of purchasing Warner Bros.' vast suite of intellectual properties and television and movie studios, including HBO and HBO Max. 

"This acquisition will improve our offering and accelerate our business for decades to come," said Netflix co-CEO, Greg Peters, in a press release. "Warner Bros. has helped define entertainment for more than a century and continues to do so with phenomenal creative executives and production capabilities. With our global reach and proven business model, we can introduce a broader audience to the worlds they create‚Äîgiving our members more options, attracting more fans to our best-in-class streaming service, strengthening the entire entertainment industry and creating more value for shareholders."

Related:Epic bets against Horses, Russia bans Roblox, and Saudi Arabia wants the majority of EA - Patch Notes #33

Netflix claims the combination will ultimately offer more choice, more opportunities, and more value to consumers. The streamer said it expects to maintain Warner Bros.' current operations while building on the company's strengths, including theatrical movie releases. At the same time, it outlined plans to realize at least $2 billion to $3 billion of cost savings per year over the course of three years. 

"By adding the deep film and TV libraries and HBO and HBO Max programming, Netflix members will have even more high-quality titles from which to choose. This also allows Netflix to optimize its plans for consumers, enhancing viewing options and expanding access to content," reads an announcement. "A stronger entertainment industry: This acquisition will enhance Netflix‚Äôs studio capabilities, allowing the Company to significantly expand U.S. production capacity and continue to grow investment in original content over the long term which will create jobs and strengthen the entertainment industry." 

Warner Bros. Games included in $82.7 billion deal

For those operating within the game industry, however, there is an elephant in the room. Warner Bros. Games (and indeed, any mention of the word 'games' outside of name-drops for Squid Game and Game of Thrones) was largely absent from the announcements and SEC filings issued by both companies. 

Related:Wreckreation developer puts entire studio on redundancy notice

Warner Bros. Games was briefly referenced during a conference call held this morning, when the Mortal Kombat logo was shown on a 'Business Overview' slide to highlight Warner Bros.' wider game and consumer product exploits‚Äîbut that blink-and-you'll-miss-it-moment was largely it. 

Then, in a brief call with Game Developer, a Warner Bros. Discovery spokesperson confirmed the recently-restructured video game division, which includes studios such as Mortal Kombat creator NetherRealm, Batman: Arkham developer Rocksteady, and LEGO custodian TT Games, will be joining Netflix. 

To what end remains to be seen. 

The rest of the chatter between Netflix co-CEOs Greg Peters and Ted Sarandos was acutely focused on the movie and television business and the reach of Warner Bros' franchise slate. 

"Warner's IP and library accelerates our ability to execute on the goal that we've always had, to deliver more and even better content for our consumers and to entertain the world by offering audiences more of what they love," said Peters during the call. 

Related:Sony partners with J.J. Abrams' Bad Robot Games as producer and publisher

"We expect to attract and retain more subscribers, drive more engagement and generate incremental revenue and operating income. We think this acquisition will make Netflix even better and accelerate our business for decades to come." 

The transaction is expected to close in 12 to 18 months and remains subject to regulatory approval.

About the Author

Senior Editor, News, GameDeveloper.com

Game Developer news editor Chris Kerr is an award-winning reporter with over a decade of experience in the game industry. His byline has appeared in notable print and digital publications including Edge, Stuff, Wireframe, International Business Times, and PocketGamer.biz. Throughout his career, Chris has covered major industry events including GDC, PAX Australia, Gamescom, Paris Games Week, and Develop Brighton.

item.title: Don't Worry, Nintendo's Working On A Fix For Some Kirby Air Riders Bugs
item.content:encoded:
Timer trouble

Kirby Air Riders arrived on Switch 2 just a few weeks ago and, for the most part, it has proven to be a pretty polished experience. Of course, that isn't to say the odd bug didn't slip through the net, but don't worry, Nintendo knows about 'em.

A new post on X from @nintendo_cs (translated by @Oatmealdome on Bluesky), Nintendo stated that it is aware of two bugs in particular, and it's working on a fix. First, there's the City Trial 'Dyna Blade' event, which Nintendo has noticed isn't showing up as often as it should. There's also a glitch in the Free Run timer, where it stops counting if the mode is used for too long.

It seems that the latter of these two bugs only applies if Free Run is played for a really long time, mind you. X user @maziari1105 shared a clip of their timer maxing out after running the mode for a whopping 116 hours ‚Äî so don't worry about leaving it on for an hour or two!

Nintendo has given no indication of when a patch will be released to remedy these issues, though we'd be surprised if we don't see it soon enough.

We had a blast with Kirby Air Riders when it launched on Switch 2 last month, calling it "a cracking sequel" in our 8/10 review.

Have you noticed either of these Air Riders bugs? Let us know in the comments.

[source x.com, via bsky.app]

Jim came to Nintendo Life in 2022 and, despite his insistence that The Minish Cap is the best Zelda game and his unwavering love for the Star Wars prequels (yes, really), he has continued to write news and features on the site ever since.

item.title: Samsung microSD Card Falls to $0.08 per GB After Skipping Black Friday, the Cheapest Storage Option for Switch and Steam Deck
item.content:encoded:
There are so many great games out there to play but so little space on the Nintendo Switch to download them all. The system‚Äôs built-in capacity fills up quickly, especially if you prefer digital purchases. Fortunately, expanding your available space is not only possible, but simple, affordable, and officially supported. Samsung‚Äôs microSDXC memory card, designed specifically for the Nintendo Switch family of systems, is currently part of a limited-time sale at Amazon. The 1TB model, normally priced at $122, has dropped to just $85, giving players a substantial 30% discount on one of the best storage upgrades available.

See at Amazon

Support a Massive Library of Nintendo Switch Games

If you‚Äôve owned a Switch for a decent length of time, you‚Äôve likely hit your storage limit. Even the Nintendo Switch OLED model, released in 2021, includes only 64GB of internal storage. The original 2017 Switch offers just 32GB, and with a portion of that dedicated to essential system files, you really have only about 25GB free for games.

To put that into perspective, The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom comes in just over 16GB. That‚Äôs a reasonable file size compared to blockbuster games on other platforms, but on a Switch, it takes up a significant chunk of your available storage all by itself. Two or three larger games can easily fill an entire console, forcing you to constantly delete and redownload titles as you want to revisit.

This is why a large-capacity microSD card is almost mandatory. By adding the Samsung microSDXC card, you expand your Switch‚Äôs storage by up to 1TB. That‚Äôs more more than 30 times the internal space of the base model system. With that much room, you can download huge first-party adventures, tons of indie favorites, and even bulky third-party releases without worrying about shuffling files around. For most players, it‚Äôs enough space to last for years.

The Samsung 1TB microSDXC card delivers read and write speeds of up to 180 MB/s, which is more than sufficient for the Nintendo Switch. It‚Äôs reliable, fast, and optimized for smooth performance while launching games or transferring data.

And we haven‚Äôt even talked about the best part yet. This SD card has Shadow the Hedgehod on it. This whole lineup of Samsung microSDs features a Sonic character. The 128GB model is marked red with Knuckles, the 256GB one marked orange for Tails, and the 512GB card is accented blue with Sonic. And then at the full 1TB, we have the ultimate lifeform himself in black‚ÄîShadow the Hedgehog.

It‚Äôs inherently very silly to me to put anything remarkable on the outside of a microSD card designed for the Nintendo Switch. That‚Äôs mainly because you‚Äôll look at it once, pop it into your console, then never look at it again. I guess you can rest easy knowing Shadow is looking after your digital copies of Super Mario RPG and Snipperclips.

Do note that this microSD card is not compatible with the newly released Nintendo Switch 2. The new console requires faster read and write speeds that you can find on an express microSD. This particular lineup of microSD cards are, however, still compatible on any of the first generation of Nintendo Switch consoles. This includes the Nintendo Switch, the Nintendo Switch Lite, and the Nintendo Switch OLED.

See at Amazon

item.title: Insider Gaming‚Äôs The Game Awards 2025 Winner Predictions
item.content:encoded:
The Game Awards 2025 has an absolutely stacked lineup of nominees and awards. There are so many categories where it could go either way, and Insider Gaming has boldly put its reputation on the line to pick the winner for every TGA 2025 category.

From Best Debut Indie Game to Best Narrative to the coveted Game of the Year award, you already know we are in for three hours of drama come The Game Awards 2025 night. Insider Gaming has already told you how to vote for The Game Awards 2025; now it‚Äôs time to tell you what we think.

Who Does Insider Gaming Think Will Win Game of the Year At The Game Awards 2025?

Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is Insider Gaming‚Äôs pick for Game of the Year at The Game Awards 2025.

It seems only fitting to give the biggest award more of a breakdown. Spoiler alert: This is not the first time Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 is going to reign supreme in a category. New-studio Sandfall Interactive‚Äîcomprised of former Ubisoft devs‚Äîset out to create something different and unique with Clair Obscur: Expedition 33.

The gamble paid off and continues to pay off late into 2025. Here are a handful of accolades the game has achieved this year:

  • Clair Obscur: Expedition 33 sets record as 2025‚Äôs best third-party Xbox Game Pass release.
  • It breaks a staggering The Game Awards record.
  • It‚Äôs shipped 5 million units.
  • Clair Obscur received acclaim from the French President.
  • A movie is already in the works.

Let‚Äôs make this clear: This is who Insider Gaming thinks will win, but necessarily who the team wants to win. However, it‚Äôs hard to ignore the buzz and brilliance of Clair Obscur: Expedition 33, and IG predicts it will scoop the big one, along with many other awards.

All The Game Awards 2025 Winner Predictions

Here‚Äôs a complete rundown of all 29 The Game Awards categories, with Insider Gaming‚Äôs predicted winner highlighted in bold to make it clear.

item.title: Tiny Bookshop coming to PS5 on April 10, 2026 alongside physical edition
item.content:encoded:
• PS5
  • Switch

Cozy management game currently available for Switch, PC.

Publisher Skystone Games and 2P Games, and developer neoludic games will release cozy management game Tiny Bookshop for PlayStation 5 on April 10, 2026 alongside a physical edition distributed by Silver Lining Interactive for PlayStation 5 and Switch, the companies announced.

Tiny Bookshop first launched for Switch via Nintendo eShop and PC via Steam on August 7. It has sold over 500,000 copies since launch.

‚ÄúSeeing Tiny Bookshop grow from a passion project into a game enjoyed by over half a million players has been incredible,‚Äù said neoludic games game designer David Zapfe-Wildemann in a press release. ‚ÄúBringing a physical edition to fans lets them keep a piece of Bookstonbury-by-the-Sea on their shelf.‚Äù

Here is an overview of the game, via Skystone Games:

Leave everything behind and open a tiny bookshop by the sea in this cozy narrative management game.

Stock your Tiny Bookshop with different books and items, set up shop in scenic locations, and run your cozy second-hand bookshop while getting to know the locals.

Decorate your Tiny Bookshop with the items you collect. Are you into absolutely plastering it with plants? Maybe a spooky candle-lit atmosphere is more your style? Every item also has an effect on your customers and can introduce new mechanics.

Recommend the right book to the right person ~ or try to expand their literary horizon? Sometimes they just need a little help finding a book they will love!

Befriend Bookstonbury‚Äôs quirky cast of characters and help each other out! They‚Äôre friendly, promise :)

Stock books of different genres to satisfy the locals‚Äô reading habits and watch your customers trickle in. Every place around town attracts a slightly different crowd, so get to know your audience and become a master bookseller!

Explore the scenic places of charming Bookstonbury-by-the-Sea and learn the ins and outs of the town. Discover its long history ~ what happened at Bookston Burgh? And who really was St. Bookston?

Discover secrets, collect items and grow your stamp collection as you explore the nooks and crannies of Bookstonbury. Who knows what else you‚Äôll find?

Watch a new trailer below.

Physical Edition Announce Trailer



https://www.gematsu.com/2025/12/tiny-bookshop-coming-to-ps5-on-april-10-2026-alongside-physical-edition

item.title: Honkai: Star Rail version 3.8 update ‚ÄòMemories are the Prelude to Dreams‚Äô coming soon
item.content:encoded:
• PC
  • PS5
  • Smartphone

Return to the "Planet of Festivities" and discover the unseen side of the Penacony journey with The Dahlia.

The version 3.8 update for Honkai: Star Rail, dubbed ‚ÄúMemories are the Prelude to Dreams,‚Äù is coming soon, developer miHoYo announced.

Here is an overview of the update, via miHoYo:

As the epic journey of Amphoreus comes to an end, the Astral Express will focus on Penacony before embarking on its next space fantasy destination. This time the ‚ÄúPlanet of Festivities‚Äù emanates a completely different aura from before, and players will have the opportunity to explore the untold mysteries alongside the new limited five-star character Constance ‚ÄúThe Dahlia.‚Äù Meanwhile, challenging enemies and distinctive limited-time events will be introduced, weaving together an adventurous journey through the galaxy filled with danger, opportunities, and rewards.

Penacony, Land of Dreams, is a vacation spot where interstellar visitors gather to celebrate and have fun. In the previous chapter during the Charmony Festival, the members of the Astral Express successfully awakened those who had fallen into beautiful dreams, empowering them to take control of their own reality. However, beneath the seemingly perfect journey lie many unresolved mysteries. After the final battle of Amphoreus, Constance ‚ÄúThe Dahlia‚Äù appears unexpectedly, revealing that the Trailblazer‚Äôs memories are incomplete and that some key parts have been stolen. With her assistance and guidance, the Trailblazer will work to piece together a complete and true storyline of Penacony.

In version 3.8, the Trailblazer will experience the story through Firefly‚Äôs perspective: how she initially entered the dreamscape, how she met us, and the battlefields she must face. All these questions will be answered one by one. As we follow her journey, The Family‚Äôs seat of power and the Dream of Gnawing Oak will also emerge from the depths of memories. Additionally, Firefly will encounter an old friend, closely connected to her past as a Glamoth Iron Cavalry Knight.

  • ‚ùÆ
  • ‚ùØ

As a key part of Penacony‚Äôs memory-hunting adventure, The Dahlia will also join the roster as a playable character. She arrives in Penacony despite her father Duke Inferno‚Äôs grand plans being ultimately abandoned. The Dahlia‚Äôs target is the Remembrance, and her power is also related to that path, with the ability to enkindle and fabricate memories. She has a long history with the Garden of Recollection and Black Swan, and it is said that she has grown accustomed to betrayal. Nevertheless, The Dahlia will assist us in reclaiming the lost memories and completing the entire Penaconian trailblazing expedition. These memories hold special significance not only for the Trailblazer, but for her as well.

The Dahlia, a five-star character following the Path of Nihility, excels when teamed up with characters who specialize in Break DMG. On the battlefield, she can actively unleash a gloomy Zone. While this Zone lasts, Toughness Reduction inflicted by allies can trigger Super Break DMG, even before the enemies have their Weakness Broken. Additionally, as a graceful and elegant dancer, The Dahlia invites a teammate to become ‚ÄúDance Partners.‚Äù After either of the two Dance Partners attacks an enemy target, they will deal an additional instance of Super Break DMG. On that foundation, her Ultimate applies every Dance Partner‚Äôs Type Weakness to all enemies, enhancing Toughness Reduction effectiveness.

Besides, in the upcoming version, a brand-new event titled ‚ÄúThe Chrysos Awoo Championship‚Äù is set to begin. The Trailblazer, as a special guest, will take on the role of a chimera trainer, leading their own little chimeras to form a powerful team in pursuit of championship glory. Additionally, the event ‚ÄúRemnants of Twilight‚Äù will also be available, featuring a variety of battle challenges that will require players to think strategically and act decisively.

Honkai: Star Rail is available now for PlayStation 5, PC via client download and Epic Games Store, iOS via App Store, and Android via Google Play.

Updates on Monster Hunter Stories 3: Twisted Reflection and Monster Hunter Wilds.

Capcom will host a Monster Hunter Showcase on December 8 at 2:00 p.m. PT / 5:00 p.m. ET / December 9 at 7:00 JST, the company announced. You will be able to watch it on YouTube (English, Japanese).

The broadcast, hosted by Monster Hunter series producer Ryozo Tsujimoto, will feature the latest information on Monster Hunter Stories 3: Twisted Reflection, as well as a deep dive into the content of Monster Hunter Wilds Free Title Update 4 ahead of its launch on December 16.

Monster Hunter Stories 3: Twisted Reflection is due out for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, Switch 2, and PC via Steam on March 13, 2026. Monster Hunter Wilds is available now for PlayStation 5, Xbox Series, and PC via Steam.

item.title: Path Of Exile 2's 1.0 Release Has Been Delayed, Dev Hopes It Won't Slip To 2027
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Path of Exile 2 is playable now in early access, but the game's 1.0 release isn't ready yet--and it won't be here soon, it seems. Grinding Gear game director Jonathan Rogers said in an interview that the Tencent-owned studio will likely not hit the previously hinted March 2026 window.

"I'm fairly confident that we won't be out of 2026," Rogers told Eurogamer. "But as I said, I never want to really completely promise anything. But I don't think it'll end up being March; we'll have to see."

There is no "specific timeline" for when Path of Exile 2's 1.0 release will arrive, but Rogers said he "certainly" hopes it won't be any later than the end of 2026.

"Obviously we're trying to get there as fast as we can, but I certainly wouldn't want to slip into 2027," he said.

In other news, Grinding Gear has announced a new update for Path of Exile 2, The Last of the Druids, which is coming on December 12. This update allows players to become a wolf, bear, or wyvern, while the update also includes a balance overhaul, in-game performance optimization, and an expanded passive tree with more than 250 skills.

Finally, Grinding Gear announced a free weekend for Path of Exile 2, coming up December 12-15.

Path of Exile 2 was released in early access back in December 2024. You can buy the game now for $30, while it will transition to free-to-play for its 1.0 launch, whenever that comes. The game is available across PC, PS5, and Xbox Series X|S.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Sony London's cancelled fantasy multiplayer seemingly gets new lease of life in Cast Outs
item.content:encoded:
Last night, Twisted Works lifted the lid on its upcoming fantasy London-set online co-op combat game. If you think that concept sounds familiar, you are not alone.

Twisted Works was established last year, with veteran developers from PlayStation London Studio, Guerrilla Cambridge, Creative Assembly, Disney Interactive, Square Enix, Blu, Slide London and more all lending their pedigree to the team.

And, it seems that some of the developers' previous work had more than a just a small influence on the upcoming release, Cast Outs, which bears a striking resemblance to artwork for London Studio's own cancelled online game for the PlayStation 5 that was to be set in a fantasy version of the UK capital.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Just like London Studio's now-cancelled game, Cast Outs is also an online co-op game set in an urban fantasy-inspired London. In the words of Twisted Works, Cast Outs is "fantasy in a modern jacket", where up to four players can team up together and use magical spells to traverse the city and defeat enemies.

You can check out the trailer for Cast Outs below.

"Cast Outs brings you the pure spectacle of magic where spellcasting hits with the physical impact of a brawler and the immediate kick of a shooter. Dive into the ultimate magical urban battleground where you and your friends can truly cooperate, regardless of skill level," reads the official blurb. "It's the perfect balance of quick-fix fun and high-octane action, built to be played together."

And, as you can see in the images below, art for both games has similar iconography and colour schemes:

Cast Outs is set to debut on PlayStation 5 and PC via Steam. A release date is still to be announced. How do you think it looks?

London Studio was shut down in February of last year, when Sony laid off 900 people, equating to eight percent of its then-workforce.

item.title: Netflix acquires Warner Bros. in $82.7bn deal, including studios behind Mortal Kombat and Hogwarts Legacy
item.content:encoded:
"We will ensure people everywhere will continue to enjoy the world's most resonant stories."

Netflix has announced it's acquiring Warner Bros. in a deal worth $82.7bn, including its game studios.

Back in June, Warner Bros. Discovery announced the company would be split between Streaming & Studios (including Warner Bros. Motion Picture Group, DC Studios, and HBO among others) and Global Networks (including sports and news TV brands like CNN and TNT Sports).

It's the former half that Netflix is set to acquire, with the transaction closing in 12-18 months once the split takes place, subject to regulatory approvals. At the time of the split announcement, David Zaslav, president and CEO of Warner Bros. Discovery, said it will "invigorate each company by enabling them to leverage their strengths and specific financial profiles. This will also allow each company to pursue important investment opportunities and drive shareholder value."

Warner Bros.' game studios includes the likes of Rocksteady (the Batman Arkham series), NetherRealm Studios (Mortal Kombat), and Avalanche Studios (Hogwarts Legacy).

It's currently unknown how the gaming division of Warner Bros. will be impacted by the Netflix acquisition. While gaming isn't mentioned specifically in Netflix's press release, "games and consumer product and experiences" were included during a webcast on the news. Hogwarts Legacy at the least was a huge revenue driver and a sequel is extremely likely, while DC fans will surely be hopeful Rocksteady is reportedly working on a new Batman game to follow its celebrated Arkham Knight series.

"Our mission has always been to entertain the world," said Ted Sarandos, co-CEO of Netflix. "By combining Warner Bros.' incredible library of shows and movies - from timeless classics like Casablanca and Citizen Kane to modern favorites like Harry Potter and Friends - with our culture-defining titles like Stranger Things, KPop Demon Hunters and Squid Game, we'll be able to do that even better. Together, we can give audiences more of what they love and help define the next century of storytelling."

Netflix co-CEO Greg Peters added the acquisition will "improve our offering and accelerate our business for decades to come".

"Today's announcement combines two of the greatest storytelling companies in the world to bring to even more people the entertainment they love to watch the most," said Zaslav. "For more than a century, Warner Bros. has thrilled audiences, captured the world‚Äôs attention, and shaped our culture. By coming together with Netflix, we will ensure people everywhere will continue to enjoy the world's most resonant stories for generations to come."

As for Warner Bros. Games, in June it initiated a dramatic leadership shift as part of a refocus on its biggest franchises, like Mortal Kombat, DC, Harry Potter, and Game of Thrones. It follows a turbulent time for the company, which saw a 48 percent decrease in games revenue earlier this year due to not releasing any games.

That followed a reported cancellation of a planned expansion to Hogwarts Legacy; Suicide Squad flopping and Rocksteady suffering layoffs; the shutdown of brawler Multiversus; and the cancellation of Monolith Productions' Wonder Woman game.
